review_content: Old Untappd checkin, February 14, 2016. Brown glass bottle. Sweet malty aroma. Bold malt flavor, sweet finish.

This is a backlog rating from 2007 from a bottle shared by Tmoney99, from notes. When I had this beer it was average to below average for the style and not something I wanted to have again or I just didn't get back to my notes because of my technology at the time, work and/or family. Words to describe this beer are caramel, boring lager malts, light earthy, meh.
bottle in NL, pours amber orange with small to medium head. Notes are roast, sweet malt, corn, and grain. Prefer the Ice Cold Heineken or Amstel over this one.

비버 : 탄맛이 남....  ..... 음 .....   

혜지몬 : 맛있긴한데 또 사 먹을 거 같진 않다... 향은 쓰고...... 맥주가 자기주장 강한 거 같은데 또 사 먹을 것 같진 않아
Bottle shared by the Luttons. Thanks! Thin cola appearance. A touch of nutty grain. Toasty, bready malt. Cool, thin finish. Alright brew.

Bottle in Bellingham. Thanks to my brother for grabbing this in Incheon for us. Tan, foamy head. Brown cola. Nutty, burnt aroma. Brown malts, sweet, a bit fruitier than I would have expected. Not bad, but burnt rubber flavor isn’t too pleasant.
Can (Seoul). Dark brown colour, steady beige head. Industrial nose has caramel, toasted malts. Light-bodied. Sugary, a bit toasted, grassy flavour. Short finish. Quite useissa.

500 ml can bought at 7-Eleven on Shantung Street, Mong Kok.



Clear dark amber red colour; Three finger head with crumpety light beige foam which last for 3 minutes; Good sticky lacing with fizzy carbonation; Sweet aroma of Amber malt, with notable roastyness, strong caramel, sticky toffee, red fruits, cream, floral, icing sugar, bread and light grass; Close to medium sweet taste of Amber malt, with fairly strong roastyness, metallic, tartness, caramel, light toffee, red fruits, floral, fair molasses, faint spices, bread, lemon, mid to light bitter hops and grass; Mid to light body. Quite watery and slick palate; Mouth feel is good Amber maltyness in a thinned but slick background. Good caramel, toffee and red with strong wheaty tartness. Flowery with moderate molasses, light bready with lemon to round. Quite okay!... Hoppiness is floral and light grass in nose. Light spice, floral, lemon and grass in taste; Bitterness is fair for an abrupt, mid to low astringent sweet-bitter caramel malty finish; Slightly dry after taste. Sweet toffee fruity and slightly bitter to mouth.



Comments: This is a macro Amber, but a competent one - Roasty amber malt with strong caramel and red fruits, restrained sweetness with moderate lemony hops. Only the body is a wee bit watery, otherwise it is agreeable and drinkable for couch potatoes!

Can from supermarket in Seoul. Light dark color, beige head. Bittter taste with nuts, malts, toast, cardboard and a bit chocolate. Bitter finish with nuts, malts, cardboard, toast and a bit of dark fruits. Pretty awful stuff.

Thick tan head on top of a dark brown body. The smell is subtle or I have a cold. Hints of coffee that's about it. It falters on the palette towards the end  but the flavors are good and distinct.  This is one of my favorite beer styles and this beer is a great reason why.
Can. Clear deep brown color almost without head. Aroma - Malt, caramel, metal. Taste - Bittersweet, mushrooms, dirt, malt. Strange.

From old tasting notes. Clear reddish brown color with a big foamy tan head. Molasses-like roasted malt aroma. Sweet roasted malt flavor with a smooth malty finish. Pleasant semi-sweet aftertaste. Nicely balanced and flavorful.

Ok then, I’ll rate this one and mostly all of the 20 some beers I haven’t rated are coming next. This stuff tastes like caramel syrup water, smells the same. It’s balance is all out of whack. It’s not as bad as a few beers that I’ve rated lower, but I can’t understand most beer drinker’s taste. I guess that’s a good thing. This may get dumped where the Colt 45 went!

I enjoyed this beer. I love Heineken and I enjoy stouts so it was easy for me to decide to try it. I found it pretty good, but not an "OMG" moment

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Pours a dark brown with a small off white head. Fairly thin body with a slight aroma of sweet malts. Pretty ordinary and not very remarkable. Not much flavor at all. Just a hint of some roasted sweet malts in the taste.

Pours a dark brown with a small off white head. Fairly thin body with a slight aroma of sweet malts. Pretty ordinary and not very remarkable. Not much flavor at all. Just a hint of some roasted sweet malts in the taste.

one of my favorite everyday beers. has a great "barley berry" or "dark fruit of the grain" flavor. Leaves your palate with a good grape-ish flavor that I find more attractive than most of the other International pasteurized dark lagers now available from Germany. Since its pasteurized it travels well in the summer for distribution in the USA. Code date is 5 for 2015 and the day of the year follows 032 being Feb 1st, etc. 2-4 months after brew date is acceptable. Einbecker Schwarz is one of the few pasteurized german beers and is maybe better overall but doesn’t match the palate that Heineken Dark leaves. A underrated/hidden masterpiece for International pasteurized lager.
Brown color ; medium-sized off-white head . Nice aroma of roasted malt , bread and caramel. Taste is weaker and too sweet . Not bad at all.
Bottle. Pours dark brown, with slowly diminishing white head. Aroma of light coffee. Taste, coffee and malts, sweet.
Bland malt taste with insufficient hops. Good color. Small head. It tastes somewhat watery. A mass produced beer with little attention to detail.

I prefer this over the regular Heineken lager, but I think it is mainly because I prefer dark beers. The flavor is more syrupy of course: caramely, malty, maybe a little bit more hops to offset the sweets. Pours an copper-medium brown color. Not heavy though like a lot of other dark beers. They don’t offer it at a lot of places, especially with the flood of micro-brews flooding the market lately, but if they ever say "Heineken", ask if they have Heineken Dark if you haven’t tried it yet. Worth the try for sure if you like the regular Heiny Lager.
Poured from a 12 oz bottle into a pint glass. This is a much better beer than their "green meenie". it is very flavorful and is lightly carbonated. Not often seen in the states but worth a try.
De geur en de kleur laten het ergste vermoeden, maar uiteindelijk valt de smaak goed mee. Gedronken in rillix
How: Bottle Appearance: Dark amber, large head. Aroma: caramel and bread. Palate: thin body, high carbonation.

Special Dark: "wow...a Heineken CAN be drinkable. Not exactly earth shattering, but drinkable. I’m surprised. pours a pleasant brown/ruby, decent malty nose and flavor, if still a little light. as good or better than newcastle."
2 Oct 2014, bottle. copper, clear, some bubbles. nose is copper malt. thin body and moderately fizzy. toasted malt and sweet lager. decent.

Reviewed from notes.
This was poured into a pilsener glass. 
The appearance was a semi-dark red color with a light transparency about it to allow light streams of carbonated bubbles rising. The head was about a finger’s worth of white foaminess that dissipated within about a minute. 
Lacing was stringy and smooth. 
The smell had a fair toffee, light chocolate and a little bit of earthiness with a light apples.
The taste was mainly sweet and bready. The apples come back slightly. 
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a fairly decent sessionability about it. The carbonation was somewhat sharp but still lending a decent smoothness about it too.
Overall, this was a pretty good Vienna Lager I could see myself having again.

Heineken Special Dark bottle poured into pint glass.The aroma is very light but has the smell of coffee with chocolate undertones. Very dark but beautiful appearance with lots of frothy head. Tastes like coffee and chocolate one of the better dark beers.
Malty and slightly sweet, much better than normal heiny, actually a good beer smooth and malty
bottle. light brown with small head. not saying much, but it’s much better than the regular heiney. light caramel malt.
Sweet pecan nose. Clear bronze, thick tan head, good lacing. Lightly sweet, unmalted grain and pecan. Clean finish. Surprisingly decent.

Poured from 12 oz bottle into nonic glass.

Appearance: 1" off white head slowly recedes with mild lacing. Color is a reddish brown.

Aroma: mild aroma of molasses and whole wheat bread.

Mouthfeel: light and refreshing, somewhat creamy.

Flavor: chocolate, medium roasted barley, caramel, molasses with some grassy hop in the finish.

Overall: a very pleasant dark lager. Nicely done.
Solid and drinkable, doesn’t have the skunk thang going. An early intro into the fact that there was something behind fizzy yellow beer.
Not bad if you’re in the mood for it. There’s a hint of chocolate and toasted malt. Far from great, but better than I expected. Another lager for my cheap pizza category.

Bottle.

A- Caramel, toffee, spices.

A- Very dark red color, hazy liquid, tan head.

T- Slightly bitter, slightly malty, spices, toffee.

P- Medium body, average texture, average carbonation, spicy finish.

O- An upgrade from regular Heineken but it’s still lacking quite a bit.

Tastes like your having chocolate milk
  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
~This review was made some time ago via another application, and thus the specific details (beyond numerical scores) are no longer available~
As a wise man once said " Heineken? Fuck that shit! Pabst Blue Ribbon!" I say " Heineken Dark? Fuck that shit! BLATZ!!" That’s how I roll.

When Anna Geertruida Cornelia Heineken inherited the brewery from her late husband, never she thought she will create the standard for beer marketing and the finest quality beer from Holland. This dark lager resembles her character; strong but gentle, with character and savor. I prefer the dark lager to the original, more taste to the palate!

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

October 2011. From bottle. Pours amber color with a white head. Roasted malt aromas with caramel and hops. Medium body and carbonation.
Pours a pretty deep amber. Looks force carbed. Aromas of nutty malts with caramel. Could pass for a Polotmavy. Taste is caramel, toffee, tree nuts. Finishes clean. Not fucken bad.

The aroma of this beer is a mixture of dough yeast and roasted malts, and the appearance is a clear mahogany color with a small off-white head that fades to a ring quickly. The taste is surprisingly good with a mixture of slight umami, touch sweet, and slightly sour, and the palate combines a medium body, slick texture, malty finish, and a soft carbonation.
Dark amber color; Medium body; Aroma of malt, & some grain; Flavor of slight roasted malt, nice caramel, and light hops; Decent macro brew.

This a very smooth and rich beer, it's the finest beer from Heineken. The malts are nice and toasty. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Clear dark brown pour with light brown head.. Aroma of prune and nut.. Taste is malts hints of chocolare..no wht i wzs expecting

After only knowing of the regular Heineken for my whole life, discovering this piqued my interest. I gave it a try, and what a beer. Not comparable with regular Heineken. This dark later is easy to drink and has a nice strong malty taste.

Bottle at Giovan’s. Deep reddish brown, kinda newcastle colored. Offwhite head. Nose is actually kinda neat. Low molasses notes and cocoa, pale malt, faint hop. No skunk. On tasting, super clean and fresh with a light roast note trending towards cocoa. Super drinkable and likable. Huh.

Semi- transparent red-brown with a creamy, light brown head.
Aroma is toast, caramel.
Taste is malty, chocolate, caramel.
very sweet.
Tasty, but a little watery.
Wayyyyy better than regular Heinie.

Poors thin but dark. Very little to no head. Taste is malty and sweet, not unpleasant. Mouthfeel is thin and finish is weak and slightly sour

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Pours dark; minimal head.  Reasonably pleasant nose.  Easy drinking, slightly rich with moderate chocolate/mocha flavor.  Clean finish.  Definitely an improvement on the original.

Similar to many Swarzbiers, but this one is a more watered down safe version. Although it lacks character, this is a good beer- easy to drink, mild malts for a simple but tasty tune. Not much head, thinner body

Easy drinking dark. Much better than the original. Mocha-ish quality on the palate. At times tastes like you're drinking candy. There are many many many better out there, but there are also many worse. Would definitely drink again. Might be a good summer dark beer if that makes any sense.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Earlier Rating: 11/13/2012 Total Score: 4
Almost has a candy quality to it. A very serviceable, easy to find dark lager. Pick some up, you won't be disappointed.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Almost has a candy quality to it. A very serviceable, easy to find dark lager. Pick some up, you won't be disappointed.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Dark red color.  Very little head. Nice flavor not over powering.  Best Heineken I've tried.  

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Nice and dark, with a sweet smell, refreshing to say the least, overall well worth the 10 bucks

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Was served at my local grocery store. Pours a darkish wooded brown with a some foam rising atop. Smells and tastes of sodden caramel sauce, rust, spent yeast and plastic. Not going to say "meh"... but it so totally was!

Bottle. Mild roast malt, scome chocolate notes, and a good swirl brings out light fruit. Dark translucent brown, tan head, some lacing. Tasty light roast malt initial; good balance in mid plate with a little bit of tang; final is clean. Minimal aftertaste. Thin body. Good enough, but oh so mild in all aspects.

It's still Heineken, but at least with a bit more flavor. Not completely terrible, but will never drink it again.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Dark amber pour.  Small head.   Weak carbonation.  Caramel and slight coffee notes.  Also, a touch of a bready taste.   A little flat and stale.

Bottle from Happy Harry’s in Fargo, ND. Ruby-amber pour with a small tan head. A little bit of caramel and peat in the aroma. Body is a bit thin. Taste is slightly sweet with very mild bitterness. This isn’t as bad as I thought it would be.
Bottle. Eh..dark dunkel like beer. Malty and bland with some hints of nuts and chcolate. Watery and nothing speial
Caramel brown with a thin skim of brown crema.  Taste is sweet and generically weak brown with a bit of diacetyl.

Medium brown with a dark hint. and a quick disappearing tan head. Smells of malt, bread, nut and caramel. Full creamy thin body. Taste of molasses, roast, malt and caramel. Light hop finish. Enjoyable to drink but a little chemical or processed in the overall make-up but I do like it,.

Bottle picked up at Premier Gourmet Niagara Falls New York. Pours a cola like with ruby hues to the edges colour with a tan head that dies down to about a finger. Decent carbonation. Smells rather malty. Tastes like regular Heineken and a touch of cola too, malt as well. Decent.

330ml bottle pours a light brown color with a finger of off-white head that leaves some spotty lacing as it settles.  Aroma is caramel and light roasted grains with some grass.  Taste is caramel malty sweetness with some light roast bitterness and is balanced nicely.  A pretty decent darker style lager.

Deep amber with pour with red hues. Light roasted maltiness with tones of sweet caramel. Sweet medium malt, with a roasty finish. Light earthy hops with a tad of bitter. A bit fizzy with medium body. Not too bad.

12 oz bottle pours brown with a tan head.  Aroma of roasted malts and nuts.  Taste is basically the malt.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
Bottle: dark amber with a medium white head.  Aromas are sweet, Carmel.  It tastes like sweet barley with a tiny roastiness.  Good, drinkable beer.  Under appreciated in my opinion.

12 oz bottle at Brazilia Grill.  Pours dark amber with short lived white head.  Aroma is of caramel and a lot of dark fruit.  Body is light and smooth.  Taste is similar to aroma with mostly fruit and caramel, slight hint of hops. Short, sweet finish. It was Ok with steak, better than other selections at this place.

Pours a light tan head that fades quickly leaving no lace. Clear deep amber color. Medium bodied and very light carbonation. Sweet malty nose. Starts sweet finish is like a dry root beer. Better than their lager.

I despise normal Heineken, so I was surprised that this was pleasantly drinkable. It’s a bit lighter than your normal "dark" beer, somewhat sweet malty, with small amounts of dark malt bitterness. Not bad.
bottle, aroma, malty, weak watery thoguh, color, dark amber hue strong white head, taste, malty, thats about it, overall, good easy drinkin beer, that makes the 80"s seem awesome

Dark Amber color, nice frothy head.   Some caramel malt aroma.  Med-light sweetness, slight bitter.  Light body, ave carbonation.  Kind of lacking in taste and body, but pretty smooth anyway.   This beer still deserves better than the ave rating.
Dark brown with off-white head. Faintly sweet aroma. Taste is kind of sweet, watery. Not very interesting.

Bottle @ home. Pours a clear, reddish brown appearance with an initially large, brown head that dissipates pretty quickly. Dark toffee/caramel malty, bland lager aroma. Fairly light bodied for the style. Light caramel malty, light chocolate, earthy flavor. Not favorable but not very good either.
Pours dark with a tanned head. Not to shabby, some sweet roasted malts, a little watery.
Smooth and refreshing sweet malty dark lager, much better than I expected. Light body and with a slightly bitter finish.
Thanks to Sean for this. Imagine if you had a beer that tasted just like Heineken but dark. Same sort of sweet flavor that Heineken has. A little roasted maltiness but not very much. Serving: Bottle
Haven’t seen this beer in years, and never in Europe.  Very sweet, but not so much it can’t be enjoyed.  Deep red color, virtually no aroma.
Golden brown color.  Malty nose, pleasant. Clean unchallenging attack and finish. A very easy to drink brown beer.

Tasted from bottle into standard pint glass. Poured a clear, dark reddish brown color with moderate off-white head which dissipated fairly quickly, leaving little lace. Aromas of grain, candy, roasted barley, no late hops, some faint fruity esters. Flavor was very malty-sweet, only slight hops bitterness, extremely roasty and dry. Light body, average carbonation, somewhat watery mouthfeel. Crisp, dry finish, no real aftertaste. Some of the "musky" Heineken hops would actually add something here. Pretty decent overall. The website lists the ingredients as barley, hops, water and yeast (no adjuncts.) It’s definitely a German-style lager, so shouldn’t it be categorized as a Dunkel instead of American Dark Lager?
Pours very dark red with no head. Nonexistent aroma. Flavor is way too sweet malts. Almost undrinkable because of the sweetness.

Draught @ JC Sjiwa, Baarlo.

Pours dark red colour with small head. Aroma of caramel and malts, some light grass and toffee also. Flavour is very sweet caramel malts and sugar candy. Medium carbonation, way too sweet a palate for such a watery mouthfeel. I’d rather drink the pale lager.

5312

Purchased from the Glenway Crossing Remke/Biggs in Cincinnati, Ohio - Alright, I prefer this brew to the regular Heineken Eurolager, and I watched closely as my lager glass filled with this dark brown, tan headed brew was poured, with a bitter roasted aroma filled my nose. Tastewise, this one is clean tasting, with a sharp, bitter finish.

~Strong malty aroma of caramel, toffee, roasty and bready. Melanoidins. Reminds me of a bock.
~Pours a clear reddish dark brown with small off white head.
~Malty roasty, caramelly and biscuity flavor.
~Med light bodied, med high CO2, light roasty finish.
~Enjoyable Lager. Much better than I was expecting. Great malty profile.

Brown, decent head.  Aroma is as you would expect - toasty malt.  The flavor is soft with with and decent bitterness - just a bit "light" on the flavor.  I can’t help but feel it’s rated a bit lower here than it deserves.
Dark brown.  Aroma is malt and grain. Flavor is roasted malt and caramel. Not bad for a macro.
Bottle. Dark chocolate, toffee aroma. Similar taste with some carbonation and a watery taste overall. Not quite on a Guinness level but close. 5% alcohol.

Overall not bad for a dark larger, it was a little sweeter than I preferred.  Has a roasted malty and sweet flavor.  Not well balanced, but a smooth finish.  It doesn’t have that Heineken larger finish to it.  Not worth the price of an import, but for the right price, this brew is drinkable.

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a dark orange-brown color with a medium sized tan head that lingered and left good lacing.  The aroma was faintly tangy with moderate bread, toffee a touch of nut. The flavor was tangy and sour with a faint nutty malt presence, a hint of toffee and not a whole lot more going on. Medium length tangy finish. Medium body. Eh.
12oz bottle pours brownish with a khaki head.  Aromas of roasted malt straw and hay.  Flavor is a bit bitter but slightly muted.  Body is medium and finish is dry.  Drinkable

Pours a very pretty dark chestnut brown with mahogany highlights and fair tan head. Semi-sweet caramel malty.  Flavor is similar, but with toffee, and a little faint nuttiness. Clean, but with a somewhat mellow quality. This beer is actually pretty damn good imho.

Found in Seoul, South Korea.  Can’t believe I paid the equivalent of $8 US for this!  Had to do it though.  Just as expected, regular Heineken flavors going on here with a nice, mild roast on top of it.  Decent, but still Heineken.
On tap at random bar in Amsterdam. Poured dark brown in colour with tan head. Aroma malty and sweet. Flavour similar with some roasted malts. Nothing special.
This was pretty sad stuff. Dark yes but taste like a watery mixture of what you cleaned your car with.
This is an ok drinker that has more body than the regular drinker.  The color is anemic.  The taste is corn with dark syrup.  Drink it when you are desperate.
Bottle, ten times better then regular Heineken. Burnt toast, flavor with some coffee. Malty, coffee, aroma. Deep dark chocolate color. Actually pretty good.
Dark brown appearance with a medium brown head. Aroma is sweet, slightly roasted malt. Taste is a little weak with some chocolate malts. Overall not bad, but nothing great.
Thin brownish color, and thin body. Modest head. Very light sweet, roasted malt flavor over-shadows the hops.
Malty and mildly harsh in flavor, not bad as a whole just that great, really.
I don’t know what to categorize this as, it isn’t an american style dark lager though, and who knew america even made dark lagers.

Pours a brown color with red hues, firm off-white head. Aroma of caramel malts and toffee. Flavor was rich in sweet malts, a bit of bread dough, caramel, toffee. A decent dark lager, easy to drink and refreshing without any bad aftertaste.

Clear dark cola color with a small white head. No lacing. The aroma is sweet, nutty, and a bit toasted. Light coffee and toffee flavors with nuts and slightly metallic finish. Light bodied with moderately prickly carbonation.
Pours a pepsi color with a light cream head. Has a malty light chocolate tasye that  taste a little funny. Not bad but not good.

Heineken Dark has a medium, creamy, tan head and a very dark reddish-brown appearance, with moderate carbonation.  The aroma is of malt and some sort of cream or milkiness.  Taste is unusual; very malty, with some sort of bread flavor that probably is due to the wheat component.  Mouth-feel is fairly heavy, and Heineken Dark finishes smooth.  Overall, I found this to be an unusual and interesting lager.  I highly recommend giving this a taste.

RJT

pours a maple syrup color, and the taste is caramelized molasses.  There is enough carbonation and bittering to balance the flavor in the finish.  Much stronger than regular Heineken, and good at what it tries to be.
Clear mohogany brown body with a medium creamy tan head that rapidly diminishes. Sweet molassas aroma. Sweet molassas flavor with some light fruit hints. Much better than I expected
An American Dark Lager, brewed in Europe. That’s interesting. Anyways, it’s not really that dark. Darker than regular Heineken. It’s reddish. It’s goodish.
Pours a medium to light brown color, nose is a blend of toasted hazelnut and mold, taste is mildly nutty, soapy, and watery. no residual sweetness.
This beer is a mediocre attempt at producing a dark beer. Sure, it’s better than regular Heineken, but at the same time it’s not exactly a good beer either.
Significantly better than regular Heineken, yet not great. This is the only Heineken worth drinking at all
Aroma of chocolate and roasty caramel.  Medium sweetness and low on bitterness.  Light bodied with a creamy texture.  Finishes up smooth, sessionable but nothing more.

Had from bottle from Total Wine and More.  Didn’t even know Heineken made a dark lager...pours a dark, but clear brown with a good tan head.  Aromas are faint, roasted malts and toffee.  Taste is better than I expected.  Starts toasty with a clean, malty finish.  Just a slightly bitter finish that lingers for a few seconds.  Enjoyable, crisp, clean, drinkable.  A pleasant surprise.
Clear reddish brown, thich creamy tan head, and some lacing.  Malt aroma.  Slight metallic taste, but overall malty and pleasant.  Short finish.

From the 12 fl. oz. bottle no. 927452852044.  The pour is about the color of its label...an amber red with a frothy two inch tan head  that diminshes. The aroma has light roasted caramel malts and vague hops but otherwise comes across as rather like stale bread. Thin mouthfeel but but than some macros. The taste is on the bitter side with a twist of hops at the end.  It goes down very fast.  I used to drink this one regularly many moons ago when it was still called Special Dark but I have grown so much since.  Now, it mainly makes me reminisce about days gone by.

Reddish-brown pour with a brown head. Roasted malt,sweet aroma. Crisp, roasted malt taste. A nice tasty lager. Like most imports that I have had while in the country of origin, I remember this tasting better. I at least think I remember tasting it while visiting the coffee houses in Amsterdam the month I was there.
Pours dark amber. Clear. Nose is roasted malt. Taste is caramel. Some malts. Rated 4/19/10

330 ml bottle in Germany. Had to force my way through it. Almost no flavor and the metallic aftertaste was unpleasant to say the least. Not bad looking, though. Not much to say here except it is better than the lighter Heineken.

Heineken Brouwerijen B. V.--Heineken Dark	

1996 12 oz. Bottle.  5.50% ABV.  (3.5 / 5.0)  Black Lager.

2007 12 oz. Bottle.  5.17% ABV--20 IBU’s.?  (4.25 / 5.0)  Schwarzbier.  Foamy lacy dark head.  Clear dark mahogeny red color.  Malty mild toasted toffee subtle hop front.  Creamy smooth malty toasted mild sweet toffee fruit body.  Clean smooth mild hop end.Nice rich smooth flavor.  Sampled 3/27/2007.

Only tried this beer to get an example "American Dark Lager" while studying for BJCP exam.  Not amazing but much better than I thought: an actual malt presence in aroma and flavor.  Too carbonated and light for my taste on mouthfeel and follow through.  As it warmed, it definitely began to fall compared the other dark examples at my table (felt lighter and a certain fruitiness I didn’t like).  

Given how I feel about standard Heinken and that I am not "supposed" to like it - it was alright.

Bottle.  Pours clear dark amber with a one finger off-white head that faded fast.  The nose is sweet malt and a touch of roast.   The taste is lots of caramel malt and toasted malt.  Medium mouthfeel.  Meh.  Reminds me of Fat Tire.
Found in the back of a friends fridge to which he said, "O you don’t want that, I’m probably going to throw it away." A better choice then regular heineken, not as bitter.

Pours chocolate brown with a thin tan head. Aroma is weak, mostly of "standard beer": weak hops, a little yeast, a little bread. Taste is very mild, mostly malt sweet with a little grassy tang at the end. Not very interesting, tastes like any generic lager beer.
It is better than standard Heineken, however. But that’s not saying much.

12oz bottle 1/19/10 (Binny’s Naperville)-Pours a clear medium brown with a small tan head. Aroma of roasted malt, brown sugar,  and caramel. Taste of roasted malt on the front end and then nothing. This light bodied brew is rather boring but again I wasn’t expecting much.

Pretty disappointing brew. I was hoping for something that would be light years ahead of regular Heineken but alas...I didn’t know dark beers could be so bland. Seriously this is the most tasteless dark brew I’ve ever experienced. There’s simply nothing to speak of. Close your eyes when you drink it and if you didn’t know you’d swear you were drinking some pale lager of some sort. I suppose I could say it isn’t offensive? How’s that for a glowing review?

Rather strong malty nose, brown sugar. Very little hops. 
Flavours are of brown sugar, yeast, malt. Very straight forward beer, reminiscent of Speight’s Old Dark.

Tried this in a pizza place because I could. Pours with a very quickly dissipating, cream-colored head over a ruby, clear, carbonated, body. Aroma gives you a little bit of caramel malts. Taste and palate are rather uninteresting. Caramel malts are there, a little sweetness, almost no hoppage, Still, I would take this over the normal Heineken any day.

12 oz bottle purchased as part of a mix a six at Lukas in Kansas City, Missouri.  Pour is a clear ruby amber golden with a three inch light tan head that falls noisily with limited lacing. Aroma of not too much, what is there is a mild nutty roast and some earthy dirtiness. A touch metallic as well. Taste is mild caramel nutty sweetness, some grass and hay and a pretty decent blast of diacetyl in the end - which makes it chemically sweet and dirty in the finish. Palate is thin to medium, lighter carbonation than I would have wanted and the aforementioned chemical dirtiness of the long aftertaste.

This takes me back 10 years, when we thought Heineken Dark was a crrrazy dark import... silly us.  Pours a clear ruby red color with a small tan head.  Sweet, malty aroma with some caramel.  Again, caramel and malts dominate the body.  Clean, non-abrasive finish.  Not a whole lot going on here except for sweet, crisp, easy drinking beer.  And to think, this was $0.50 cheaper than Heineken green death bottles...
Taste 10/9 bottle. Looks: A thin rimming of brown suds on a dark brown body. Aroma: Sweet malt and hay with raisin. Taste: A flat bodied overly sweet beer.
Bottle at McLoughlin’s, Kyoto Clear dark brown (red glow) - white head. Dark bread, roasted, wet dog, nutty, sweetness, caramel, light light hoppy. Plain - Macro !!!

Better than I expected - actually reminds me of a dunkelweiss - aroma has bananas and light hints of sweet malt.  Appearance is chestnut, a little clearish/watered down.  Head starts out decent but disappears to nothing along with no lacing. Flavor is smooth, again a little bit like a weissbeir.  Finish is medium bodied  and smooth.
Pours garnet-tinged brown into a shaker. Off-white head quickly recedes to hug rim. No aroma. Sharp and malty with dark dry pit fruit from front to back.
12oz bottle.  Dark with red hue.  Tan head that left fast.  Smells just like Heineken!  Way too much carbonation.  A little hint of roasted malt through the bubbles.  Not bad for Heineken.

Bottle. First time to try this world famous dark since high school, I suppose.  
Dark brown color with reddish tints, tall, fine, light tan head. Sweet, malty aroma, some dark fruits, honey, only light roasting. Rather sweet, medium light beer, caramel. Fruity, a touch of roasted flavor, but just a touch. Not too sweet, decent balance, though not very complex and could be a bit dryer. A touch of sour to balance. Not really interesting, but better than I expected.
Well ok. Its not bad. Slight roasted notes. I think the carbonation stunts some of the flavours and maybe dulls the mouth feel. Not blowing me away but I surely dont hate it.
This is a hell of a beer!  Not really, but for Heineken, this is top notch.  Actual flavors, roasted aromas that aren’t all skunk.  Incredible.

12 oz bottle, pours a clear dark color with moderate head. Aroma is just like regular Heineken but a little more roasty/chocolate present. Flavor is neutral, some malty sweetness, no bitterness. Palate is smooth. Better than the regular version, but nothing special.

12fl oz bottle poured into a dimpled mug.  Dark amber brown with one finger tan head.  Sweet malty aroma of dark fruit.  Flavor is the same with some toastiness.  Medium carbonation.  Finish is mostly sweet with some light bitterness.  Surprisingly good beer.

Single bottle into a pint glass

Pours brown with a loose tan head. The aroma is metal and dust. Flavor is bitter and dry, but not really malty or hoppy. It’s hard to pinpoint the flavors, but it’s not great.

12 oz bottle. amber with little tan head. no lacing whatsoever. first smell was actually orange. then i got sweet malt. taste like caramel that last a while. not really a fan of that long lasting sweetness. some hops. a bit watery as expected. not a bad thirst quencher though.

Bottle. A dark amber color pour with a small offwhite head, no lacing. Aroma is of lightly sweet caramel,slightly nutty,faint hops. Flavor is semi-sweet,toasty malt flavor (better than expected) lightly bitter,some caramel,with just a hint of grass. Light body,crisp clean mouthfeel, very sessionable and a  pretty good drinker

Bottle at Beer Bourbon and BBQ Festival in Richmond VA on 5-30-09. Dark brown pour. Short light tan head. Aroma is light caramel, Euro hops, grass and corny notes. Taste is toasted malts, caramel, grassy hops, slight skunked hops and more corny flavors. Body is light-medium with moderate carbonation. Ends with more of the same - grassy hops, caramel, ligh toasted malt, soft skunky notes. Drinkable but only OK at best.

12 oz. bottle.  Pours a clear, deep mahogany with a small, effervescent, light tan head.  The first aroma I got was cooked vegetables which isn’t good.  There are light malt notes, but the nose is pretty light.  Medium carbonation with a medium-light mouthfeel.  A tad on the watery side.  The taste is an odd mix of bitterness, vegetables, sweet malt, and light metallic notes.  Pretty retched stuff.  Like a Killian’s and a Heineken mixed together.  One saving grace is a short finish.  I can’t recommend this to anyone.

Dark red/brown, off-white head.  Fairly attractive.  Decent aroma of caramel malts.  The flavor was caramel, sweet, approriate amount of hop bitterness, sepecially toward the end.  The mouthfeel was thin/medium.  Decent beer overall, especially for a Heineken.
nice beer with a nice malt aroma. head dissipates fast. nice malty flavor with low bitterness. overall not bad for a heine.
Bottle.  pours a dark reddish brown with a decent tan head, the aroma is of sweet malts, yeast, & corn, taste was sweet and bready, ok body an ok drinkable beer, but nothing great.
Not too bad for a mass market brew. Kind of plain with very little to distinguish it. Carmel molasas taste, not much head. Drinkable but only barely a thumbs up.

Bottle. Pours a dark brown with a decent tan head. Aroma was slightly sweet with caramel malt, grains and a touch of molasses. Flavor was malty and sweet with roast, light caramel, a bit of chocolate and graininess and has a thin to medium body.

Bottle, pours a red amber with a thin off white head.  Aroma is malt with some sweetness maybee some caramel.  Flavor is malty clean and a little roasty.  I am drinking this while i am cooking burgers.

Bottle.  Pours dark brown with off-white head.  Nose is caramel malt, Wheaties, mild nuts.  Decent palate heft, decent complexity, with malt, grainy, figgy, and nutty flavors.  This one is a beer I would happily drink with a cigar or a summer burger.
Probably the best Heineken product out there...because it doesn’t taste like Heineken.
Northfield, MA. Dark brown with medium head. Sweet and malty nose. Taste of dark fruits, malts, and honey, even chocolate. How very un-Heineken. Slightly sour finish.

12oz bottle from package store in New Orleans. Pours a generally hazy dark brown to black color with a one finger creamy head that settles slowly and laces the glass. Aroma is sweet and malty with notes of bread, yeast, ripe dark fruit, some hints of maple syrup. Flavor is also sweet and malty with notes of bready yeast, dark fruit, some hints of chocolate and maple syrup. Generally medium body with a sour malty finish.

Poiurs a clear medium to dark brown with a tall foamy tan head that has somewhat decent retention. Aroma is sweet grain, nutty, a hint of toast, caramel, smells a bit like an average marzen. Flavor is sweet grain, toasted grain, a tiny hint of caramel, adjunct, slightly soapy, and some notes of sweet chocolate. Palate is medium-thin and highly carbonated. Not bad for a "dark beer" for the masses. Still none too impressive though, sort of like a cheap marzen.
Pours dark amber with a sweet malty aroma. Flavor is malty, not much else. No hops or skunk like the original.

12 oz bottle from the grocery store.  Poured a clear dark amber color with a one finger tan head.  The aroma was very malty, with earthy notes.  The flavor was malty, with chocolate and caramel present.
Tastes like...dirty water. The aroma is nice, very fruity and sweet smelling. I will give it that. Flavor tastes like water - dirty dishwater with a touch of sugar in it. Meh.
Dark brown in color with ruby highlights.  The head quickly reduces to nothing and leaves no brussels lace.  Aroma is malt.  There is a medium body with light caramel flavors.
Dark amber brown pour. Semi sweet malty aroma. Watery, thin mouthfeel. Light bitterness. Detectable earthy chocolate notes. Decent for a mass produced brew. Much better than the pale lager.

12oz Bottle – 99 Bottles – Federal Way, WA 

Nice beer with a good flavor and finish.  This was a well brewed mass beer.  The flavoring was simple and smooth.
no skunk, chocolate malt, nothing overly special, far more enjoyable than their pale lager

Crushed with Jakebra.  Nice.  No skunk pee, but possibly some skunk poop.  I guess thats the difference in the recipes.  Nothing good to comment upon.  Thank god for variety 6 packs.  One bottle of this shiot is enough.
Tasted 06.12.2008. 330ml bottle from beerstore. More coming... Clean, carbonic and lightly bitter.
Bottle. Pours a clear brown, nice tan head. Aroma is malts and a touch of chocolate. Flavor is again malt, cereal, a little sweet. Slight bitterness on the finish.

Pours a dark cherry wood color with a nice tan head that has good retention.  Aroma of molasses.  Flavor is roasted malt and is just a bit smokey.  There is some caramel, buttered toffee, and just a hint of earthiness that is unexpected in a macro.  Feel is thin and flat.  This is not a bad beer and is far superior to their pale lager.
Bottle.  Creative they changed the color.  Well now its a ruby dark crap lager.  Little bit of caramel malt and then that signature bitterness.  eh.
12 oz bottle at Stars Dinner Theater; Nose of caramel and very light spiciness; rusty red with a big beige head; flavor is caramel, wheatiness, and light bitterness.

12 ounce bottle from Total Wine in Richmond. GUSHER! That was not expected. Needless to say, a huge head on top of a reddish brown beer. Sweet caramel aroma with grassy and roasted grain notes. Roasted malt aroma with banana, bread and dark fruits. Medium body.
bottle, pours walnut brown, big head quickly fades, sour malt aroma, weak sour caramel flavor, thin watery finish
dark red in colour with caramel coloured head. malty/biscity flavours, short mouthfeel and thin.
12oz bottle.   Dark brown with almost no head.   Metallic and lightly burnt aroma.   Thin, buttery, lightly caramelized flavor.   Light bodied with prickly carbonation.   Ya, this does suck.

(Bottle) Pours a light brown color with a small tan head. Sweet caramel and some dry cocoa in the aroma. Taste includes some brown sugar, toffee and caramel malts. Body was a little on the light side. Could use more malt. Better than I expected... and much better than regular Heineken.

(Bottle).  Sweet caramel aroma.  Deep reddish brown color, large light brown head.  Flavor is all caramel and sweet breadiness.  Low carbonation, watery mouthfeel.  Best part is the finish, which lingers with a malty semi-sweetness.
Deep amber tone with a creamy tan head that disappeared quickly. Light malty aroma  and taste with a slightly bitter finish. Smooth on the palate but a little lacking. Not Bad.
Getting my old notebook online. Bottle. Rish dark color, strong fruit smells. Taste ok, not a lot to it. Some fruitness, hint of bitter.Tabacoish after taste. Decent session beer at best, refreshing.

12 oz bottle Total Wine. Carmelized malt accentuated aroma with hint of spicy hops. Clear dark ruby brown with small white head. Nice malty caramel and toffee notes. Clean lager body with medium mouthfeel. Hint of spicy bitterness in finish. Surprisingly good.

Medium brown frothy tan head. Aromas of slightly sweet with hints of corn, grain, chocolate and hops. All of these individual aromas are faint but the overall aroma is ok. Many of the aromas don’t seem to carry over to the flavor but there are faint hints of chocolate, grain, and barely. Slightly bitter finish. Its somewhat watery which is a major turnoff for me. Lacking pronounced flavors. Better than the original Heine lager.
Bottle. Pours red brown with a beige head. Caramel malty aroma, with a hint of salty soy. Thin body. Flavor is the same as aroma.

A bit watery, little aroma, but the flavor is pretty good.  Granted, I’d rather go with a Hofbrau Dunkel or something of the like, but overall, for the price, this is not bad, especially for a Heineken.
Poured a dark reddish color with a white head. Aroma was very subdued but was mainly malty and some caramel. Flavor was over the tops sweetness with not enough balance of hops.
What exactly is an American Dark Lager ?  Light in taste, body, aroma, flavor. Looks better than a regular Heineken, tastes just as bad. Those guys have at least on thing going for them: consistency.

From the bottle, pours medium dark with red undertones. Small carmel head that was gone quickly. Flavor is somewhat sweet with hints of raisins. I agree with cooldave. Finishes with a hint of fig. Drinkable. Have Another? Why not.
Tasted from draft in Japan in the Hardrock caffee at Yokohama. Nothing speciall and not much taste
I honestly couldn’t tell much of a difference between this and regular Heineken.  To me, this is Heineken with dark coloring.
Bottle and tap. Deeper then a puddle, maybe. Adventure is not always self evident. But examples of such may employ us to reach for something more "out of the way". Tricks are truly for kids!

I wasn’t aware that Heineken could brew something this complex.  Poured like cola with a touch of ruby red thrown in.  Aroma of dried figs and raisins.  Thin head.  Flavor is very reminiscent of Mexican sweetbread (Semita: the kind with raisins).  Very nice!  I’m hooked... I’m looking forward to purchasing more.  This also reminds me of Shiner Dunkelwiezen and Austin Amber beer.
Not quite as ordinary as the original heineken, but blah, nonetheless...perhaps a little bit more roastier???

Dark mahogany color, appearing brown with little bubbly head of tan foam that sticks a bit.

Smells mostly of diacetyl, slight bit of nuttiness and banana.

Buttery popcorn with some slight astringency that doesn’t quite seem roasty.  Not really a hop dryness as much as a drying astringency.

Medium feel with nice bubbly carbonation.  This would be drinkable if I could get past the diacetyl.

en cuanto a cervezas popularmente distribuidas y disponibles esta me gusta menos que la becks.  hay que tomarla cuando no hay mejores opciones en los star mart y vamos de paseo.  pajita pajita pajita [insertar] mas pajita para cumplir el requisito
Pretty bland overall. This brew pours a deep copper- reddish brown with a very sweet malted aroma. A mildly woody taste with a soft creamy finish.

330ml bottle. Dark brown with red highlights full fluffy tan head that settles out quick. wafts of dark malt syrup with faint chlorine(?) character. Milk chocolate, sweet malty and slight woody / burnt notes. One dimensional and goes nowhere in the finish. A little metallic carbonation also.

Pours dark brown, almost opaque but not quite. Has a huge, thick, foamy, lasting head.
Aroma of chocolate and medium/dark malts. Tastes like moderately sweet malt, and a little hops. The flavor is rich and full. The body is medium, and it has a sweet, malty finish. Good lacing.

Bottle.  Pours a dark red-brown with a thin tan head.  Aroma is of caramel, roasted malt and is rather sweet.  Taste is much the same, but a lot lighter.  Is fairly smooth, but I don’t care for the finish.  Overall, this is decent beer, but it is overpriced for what it is, as there are better choices out there that cost less.
If you dont like regular Heine, no reason you will like this.  Watery and boring.  No funk in this beer unlike its nasty big brother.  But why bother with this beer?
Bottle. Very light for a "Dark Lager" Has a nice finish with no aftertaste. Better than original Heineken. No skunky taste or aroma with this stuff.
gave this one a try.  Decent, nothing special, nothing to write home about.  But I had to give it a try.  Slipt rock beer fest.
Smooth as silk.  Not at all heavy as the label "dark lager" would create in one’s mind.  Light and crisp with a unique bite at the back of the tongue.

Pours a very dark amber color. Medium sized fizzy coke looking head that dissapates quickly. Nose is roasted, soapy, and sour, with lots of lager notes. Taste is woody, roasted, and bitter. Some chocolate. Actually not that bad.
Pours a dark amber color.  Has a slightly sweet aroma.  Taste is of mild roasted malts with touch of mollassis. Not bad for easy drinking dark lager.
Not very impressed with this extremely malty beer.  I was expecting some flavor or bitterness, but just malty malty malty.  Like an alcoholic Malta.

Pours a dark brown.  Aroma is a tad malty and nutty.  Tastes like a lager that has had spoonfuls of malt stirred around.  Seems light with a heaping of molasses sitting atop of the texture.  It’s not bad and it’s definitely a lot better than plain heineken.
Dark brown in color with ruby highlights.  The head quickly reduces to nothing and leaves no brussels lace.  Aroma is not correct for the style.  There is a medium body with light caramel flavors.

pours a very dark amber/brown with a large creamy beige head.  aroma is slightly sweet and lagerish with a touch of burnt molasses.  flavor has some brown sugar and nuttiness but also keeps lager-like profile.  i like this one.

there is some flavor here....light caramel mostly added to the regular heinie type profile of beer. decent yet still semi bullshit sweetness. decent maltiness for a macro that is light roasty hay (green hay at that). probably would not had rated this well if a micro. not bad, not good. i do like that holland small but busy carbonation. watery raisin infusion (drip of raisin flavored sweet liquid delivered from a carton) taste. eeehhh

THOUGHTS: The last of the forgotten New Year’s Eve beers. I always wanted to try this one and finally did. Almost like a schwarzbier, but not as complex, but nice.
TECHNICAL: Bottle. Poured a very dark red with a small to average off-white head that mostly diminished. The aroma was moderate caramel malt and very light grassy hops. Slight coffee was also there. The initial flavor was moderately sweet and sour; while the finish was lightly bitter and fairly sour. The flavor was caramel and roasted malt then some grassy hops with a coffee-like bitterness and sourness. The light to medium body was slightly syrupy with lightly fizzy carbonation.
Brown, medium thin with red hues. Head is sand colored, goes away fast. Aroma is sweet malt. Taste is sweet honey and soy sauce, not bad. Pretty much what I expected.

Pours a nice caramel dark brown - almost black but no sustaining head.  Not the skunky aroma of the big brother green bottle, something similar with much more pronounced roasted malt.  Taste has a little coffee, dominated by a mildly roasted malt.  Medium-bodied, this beer is not bad.  It does have a bit of a salty, bitter finish, but is  much more calm and relaxed than its green bottled brother.  To compare it to the world of rock, it’s like the Kinks - easily digestible, definably unique, enjoyable by all.

Bottle (in NZ). Looks good - pouring a deep dark red with a creamy off white head. That metalic Heineken aroma, but with a strong whiff of alcohol and a fruity and toasted malt presence. A strong malty palate, again with a strong alcohol presence. The finish is disappointly short. But pretty good - for Heineken...

pours a dark caramel color with red highlights and a one finger fluffy, bubbly, and creamy brown head. aroma is toasted caramel malt. has a medium body with descent lacing and good carbonation. flavor is the same as aroma but a bit stronger and with a little hops thrown in. a nice dark lager flavorful and smooth and no skunk anywhere. as it warms there is a bit of raisin and cinnamon in the aroma and definitely in the flavor.

I was surprised by this one, I thought it would be a slightly richer  version of regular Heineken but this is way different. I think it is a nice malty but not too heavy beer, a good amount of sweetness without going overboard. Not bad at all.

12 oz. bottle poured into lager glass- poured transparent reddish brown, off white head came and went, medium carbonation, aroma of weak roasted malt with notes of hops and sweetness.  Hits the mouth with a thin watery body, the malt is detectable at least and pleasant, finish is clean.  I won’t turn it down if at a friend’s house and it was a long session.
Bottle. Pours brown ruby, off white head. Aroma is malt, caramel, hops. Flavor is the same and watery. This has a strange mouth feel, almost chalky.
Not a bad beer, but it could be much better.  Tastes of dark, bitter fruits with a malty mouthfeel.  Could be sweeter or more lively.  All in all decent, but not better than the regular Heineken.

You can tell it’s Heineken when you taste it. If you’re picking this up thinking it will be different than Heineken lager, just put it back down. That being said, this is a pretty good dunkel; not the best by far, but certainly not an unworthy purchase. I mentioned Heine’s lager because this is literally just a dark version of their standard lager; no major difference except that it is a little thicker and has a more pleasant scent to it. I wouldn’t mind picking up a sixer of this again in the near future.

Not bad compared to the regular stuff. Moderate flowery hops with some light maltiness and a bit of cinnamon. Much better smelling than the Pale Lager. The off-white head diminishes quickly over the clear, dark amber body. Taste is malty but watery with a bitter-salty finish. Near creamy mouthfeel and lively carbonation make this a pretty smooth drinking mass produced beer.
Drank this over at Tricia’s house in Waikele.  Her brother Teddy was drinking it while eating some excellent sushi.  Was perfect match.  Malty, and tastey.

Sept. 2006 - Beer poured dark brown with ok head and minimal lacing.  Aroma was dark roast and the flavor was more of the same.  A bit thin and again something "off" in the flavor (not skunk, but more like cardboard).  Drinkable, but nothing to go looking for.
an old friend slightly bitter and strong. back in the 70s and 80s their wasn’t much to choose from here in the states started me on search for better beer

Appearance: Pours a dark reddish-brown body with a small beige head.

Smell: Lightly sweet-smelling aroma of dark malts, plums, and a hint of grain.

Taste: Watered-down dark caramel flavor with a medium sugary sweetness. Plum fruitiness. Very mild bitterness. Clean, easy finish

Mouthfeel: Light-bodied. Medium carbonation. A tad watery, I’m afraid.

Drinkability: While never complex or overly impressive, it does exhibit far more character than the standard Heineken.
had one of these in vegas at the sahara weird candy medicine taste maybe tasted worse because it wasn’t that cold

pours a big retaining tan head and deep red color.  Aroma is mild dark malt.  Taste is some sweet dark malt-molasses/some chocolate and licorice, bready, dark fruit-plum/cherry, faint hops.  Thin mouth feel at finish.  Medium body. Some doppelbock-like character.  OK carbonation.

I really don’t want to bring the scroe down on this one but...  I think the aftertaste on this beer was horrible.  Possibly I got a bad batch??  Actually my friend gave a  free 6-pack as a gift...I still have 5 in the fridge 2 months later.
Light brown translucent color, good carbonation. Aroma of grainy malt and rye. Flavor is mostly light caramel sweetness and some bitterness. Finishes somewhat on the dry side.

Poured from a bottle.  Poured a dark caramel color with a thin beige head.  Slight malt aroma.  Flavor is malty with a touch of chocolate.  Overall it is simple, but I also enjoy it more than Heineken’s regular product.
A whole lot better than regular Heineken! Crisp and clean, with a nice finish. Not much of a smell but still a good beer none the less, like a said its better than the regular!

Poured dark ruby red with little head that faded quickly. Smelled like red licorice and tasted very similar. THis brew also reminded me of an Octoberfest beer, kind of sweet and not something I enjoy drinking.

Very dark amber-caramel color. The head reminds me of a cola, and tries to linger. Sharp smooth prune nose. Taste like Optimator Spaten without the higher alcohol %. Thinner body. Malty taste. It is a solid brew without anything special about it.
Poured a dark caramel color. Aroma of dark roasted malt. Nice head retention. Sweet malt flavor, a little too sweet for me. Tast of chocolate roast malt. Not bad, but not great.
One of these usually does the job, two is just too much, really a 6 pack lasted me a month

This mild, malty brew has a nice chestnut glow in the glass and a light head.  The flavor is mostly roast grains and bread.  A harvest feel pervades this autumnal beer, and It reminded me of a Marzen.  Not particularly inspiring, but solid, enjoyable stuff - better than I expected.

Aroma of dark carmel. Dark mahogany color with a whitish head that left rapidly. Medium plus body with creamy carbonation. The flavor is roasted caramel with light hop. Fairly bland, but it has a decent taste. I’d rather have a good IPA, but this is a good drink. Better than many dunkels (not that this is one, it is just a pretty good dark beer).
Clear chestnut brown, small rapidly thinning head. Low aroma and low flavour as well, caramel. Nothing special.

This is very dark red-brown with a thick tan head that dissipates slowly but steadily to leave nothing.  The aroma is caramel and faint toasted malt.  The taste is fairly sweet, as predicted, with a hint of bitterness, somewhat toasty with caramel, morphing into a faint, unpleasant burnt taste before a fairly nice grain finish, the beer’s best quality.  It is rather fizzy and thin, with a weak, fizzy water palate that vanishes quickly to leave almost no remnant in the mouth.  The beer was better in the beginning that it was by half way through.  It has some body and flavour, but not enough to compete with its real competitors in my book, dark German beers, strong ales, ESB-types, etc.  If I’m going to drink a sweetish, bland, watery beer, I’ll stick with cheap pale lager and if I want a rich, full-flavoured beer, I’ll take one of the above.
12 ounce bottle available for around $1.25 much better than the regular Heineken

Don’t really know why I picked this up, I think i just wnted to buy some beer.  Oh well.  Deep ruby red with a fizzy tan head.  Toasted malts, molasses, brown sugar,  and a touch of coffee.  Hmm, interesting.  Fairly smooth body, but noticeable carbonation.  Flavor is malty, molassess, toasty malts, and some coffee in the end.  Finish is light, and roasted.  I was pleasently suprised with this one.

Bottle  330ml 

Appearance :Clear , brown lager with touch of ruby in it. Good , tanned rocky like top3+. 
Nose :Sweet brown malts , sugar and molasses. Light hint of roast.

Flavour/Palate : Medium light bodied. Carbonation in norm. Fairly clean in character with stronger than average molasses notes. With time felt a bit flat . Late light coffee end.

Deep, reddish brown appearance with a fast fading off white head and sparce lacing.  Muted aroma developed an off-putting chemical note as it warmed.  Slightly sweet, roasted caramel malt taste.  Medium boded, well carbonated mouthfeel that was little thin on the palate.  I included this in a blind tasting with some friends, and it was generally well liked.  Someone guessed it was a schwarzbier, another thought it was a brown ale.  When the cover came off most didn’t believe that it was a dark Heinie.
Had this one at a local restaurant.  Brown with a fizzy white head.  Faint malty aroma.  Faint taste that seemed vaguely like chocolate and roastiness.  Not great.

From bottle :Pours a very very dark  brown almost black, with a nice two finger white rocky head.  Aroma of roasted butterscotch.  Flavor is a little fruity at the end.  Palate is thin to medium bodied, then goes a little watery at the end.
Bottle - Nice Medium Dark color, smooth pour. Not a bad dark Lager overall. Was actually surprised by this one, I would drink it again.

(Bottle from Lou’s Beverage Barn) Really not too bad...Pours clear dark brown with three fingers of tan head that recede to a globby covering. Aroma, initially is kind of odd, but then there is caramel, butterscotch and coffee. Mouthfeel is rather poor, not much texture, pretty watery. Flavor is better than expected - chocolate, caramel and coffee in decent amounts - but I couldn’t decide if the flavors were "real" or somehow added.

Thanks to maniac for leaving this bottle for me.  Honestly, better than I remembered.  Clear amber brown, reddish hints, quickly fading white head.  Aroma is malty, light caramel and hint of molasses.  Flavor matches, a bit on the watery side, but overall a decent malt sweetness.  Clean finish.

A clear mahogany pour props up a compact white head that dissipates quickly and offers up no lacing.  The aroma is heavy on the malt and little else.  The flavor was malt and some sweetness.  A decent sweetness, not the corn sweetness you get the regular version.  Forgettable finish.  Thin mouthfeel.
Had this in Amsterdam, just cause I could! Clear mohogany brown body with a medium creamy tan head that rapidly diminishes. Sweet molassas aroma. Good!
Really enjoyed this beast. Nice darker (not dark dark though) color. Good place to start w/ dark beers if you ask me.

Bottle from Party Source. Poured clear brown with a large frothy off-white head that was mostly lasting with good lacing. Moderate roasted malt aroma. Medium body. Medium sweet toasted flavor with a medium sweet finish of moderate duration. Sweet drinkable beer.
This beer is a little better then regular Heineken because at least it is dark so it has a little better flavor, but I wasn’t that crazy about it.

a friend who loves skunky beer grabbed this one last night.  decent.  but thats about it.  i barely noticed a difference from this and the regular.  its not great, its not terrible.  middle of the road.
Clear mohogany brown body with a medium creamy tan head that rapidly diminishes. Sweet molassas aroma. Sweet molassas flavor with some light fruit hints. Much better than I expected.
Decent aroma of roasted coffee and caramel.  Creamy, but not too heavy.  Very easy finish.  Not bad for a Heineken beer.  Good "starter" beer for those newbies (like myself) wanting something darker.

It’s all about lowered expectations.  For so many years a ’premium’ bottled beer in my part of the world was the skunky, bitter pale lager brother of this offering.
Everyone is so used to how boring and bland the pale lager is, they are surprised when this dark lager has some taste and character.
If you are going to drink Heineken in the US, drink this.

12 oz bottle. Pours dark reddish brown with darkish head. First impression is a strange one. I figured this was some sort lager but the aroma reminded me of almost a stout. As i kept drinking it "lagered" out. Decent beer, not as good as the original - which isnt that good.
Nothing special, but a little better than the regular Heineken. It doesn’t have the skunky taste and it has a little more maltiness to it. Easy to drink, but really boring.

Overall very enjoyable beer, much better than their standard lager, smooth, going down and not as carbonated as some of their other offerings. Some caramel and toffe notes and mild malt, little hop though, would dring again.

pours nut-brown colored with a balanced tan head.  Fruity malts on the nose, mingling with raisins and toffe laced with caramel.  Nutty and malty on the taste, and mid to lite body.  Overall from a brand like Heineken there is an impressing amount of character and flavor, and that being said, a decent overall entry and a pleasing surprise for lowered expectations.

Bottle...dark red color, poured with a nice tope head. Has a sweet yet burnt taste. Taste of berry (cherry?) and malt and hops. An even mouth feel that does not overpower or really stays w/ you. No Heineken trademark taste...that means the sour flavor of the green bottle. a nice dark beer and worth a try.

12 oz bottle. Had a caramel kettle corn aroma along with some sweetness. Mahogany red body with tan head. Decent blend of sweet caramel and roasted malt for flavor. A sweet malt covers the palate on finish. Not a bad brew.

12oz brown bottle (unlike standard Heine Green)  Very dark brown.  Aroma of sweet malt and a hint of toffee and cherries!    Flavor is kinda non existent.  Malt  on the palate and that is about it.  Dark session, good call.

Very Dark Amber pour with a smallish light tan head that doesn’t last too long unfortunately.  Good looking beer.  Smell isn’t too strong to begin but the lightly malty caramel, alcohol smells I do pick up are subtle but nice at first, but then turn into an almost nauseatingly artificial syrupy caramel smell.   Tastes of some lightly roasty malts, a touch of yeast, and has a very quick finish and basically no bitterness.  Body is a tad watery, yet has a fairly rich, full flavor for a (dark)lager nonetheless.  Overall, a good easy drinking darker session beer.  Not bad by any means, but not one to satisfy a true dark beer fan looking for a big robust flavor.
Brown beer with a thin off white head.  Fairly malty aroma with dark caramel and light nuttiness.  Poor hop character.  Light nutty maltiness.  Lingering sweetness.  Meh.
A nice choice for a gateway beer when trying to break friends of their football beer dependance.

bottle. pours a dark amber with a little tan head that stays. the aroma of this one has a chocolate/coffee to it. this laces nicely and has a very caramel taste to it. one of the easier to drink "dark" lagers.

Rated 1/3/06:  Back in college I would often treat myself to a six pack if I had some extra cash or I was just feeling special. It’s a very good dunkel, completely different in taste from regular Heineken Lager. The heavier flavor and thick appearance are great. Although not real complex in flavor I think the overall taste does this beer justice. My biggest drawback is the over-inflated price of Heineken. If I want to enjoy a good dark beer I can save a couple of bucks and pick up lots of other choices just as good if not better than this one
sweeter than reg. almost caramel taste to it. interesting taste but not memberable. not too great for a dark beer.
Pours with a nice thick head. Aroma is of burnt cocoa and malt. Nice taste albeit a little weak and not quite enough hop for me on the finish.

This is an old favorite from when I first got turned on to dark beer.  That was about 1980. It’s been at least a decade since I’ve tried this and I am very eager to see how this stacks up against other dark beer I’ve rated lately.  This is not a memory rate, I drink as I rate. Stubby 12 oz brown bottle. Nice aroma when you pop the cap and pour it into the big clear mug. Very dark but not opaque. It has a brown tinge that you can barely see thru the otherwise very dark brown color. Flavor is roasty and well behaved, no hint of bitterness. It possess many of the desirable dark beer qualities without the offensiveness of the stouts. Friendly and easy to drink. Does not have too much of that regular Heinie flavors, quite surprised.  Has a bit of chewy feel to it. This is a rather decent brew. Much better in flavor than the original Heinie. How about that, an American Dark Lager brewed in Holland? Is that weird or what?  Finish is agreeable and delicious. I must mention there is just a touch of mild bitter roastyness on the back of my throat during the end of my last gulp.
Better than the original, but not a bland taste to it. It pours a dark brown color. Like I said not great, but better than the one in the green bottle.

i got this from my bro.  i usually hate heineken cuz it tastes like skunk piss and gives me a wicked bad headache.  this wasn’t too bad though.  dark brown in color with a slighly nutty taste.  it’s mostly watered down but compared to regular heinie, i’ll take it
not a true "dark" beer but a more flavorful less skunky smelling version of a holland classic.
Walk on the dark side for Heineken lovers, but those that have been on the dark side for a while wont think much of it.
Bottle: Poured a dark brown with tan head. Aroma was sweet and flowed into the sweet sryup taste. Very forgetting after drinking.

Bottle, from Duvel tulip, at cellar temp. Head is huge and frothy, but dissipates completely. Looks nice in the glass; a nearly opaque brown color. Smells...dangerous...like a powerful cleanser you might find under the kitchen sink. There’s a nutty note in there which might have been nice, but the chemical overtones are too strong. Palate is light, thin and flat. Tastes like the time I got my mouth washed out with soap for calling my mother a horrible name. I’ve since grown to understand the reasoning behind that punishment, but I fear this one will leave me scarred for life. This might actually be the first time I can’t bring myself to finish a six-pack, but I’ll do my level best. Wish me luck...

Dark brown color, with a frothy beige head, sweet toasted malt nose, with some caramelized malt notes, nutty, with a raisiny fruitiness, molasses and toffeeish aroma follows through on a medium-bodied palate with nice nutty, caramelized malt character, with a good toffeish, biscuity accent, with some raisins, dates fruitiness, a faint bitter chocolatey note, leading towards a malty, lingering bitter finish. I’m quite impressed with this beer.
not a bad beer wouldn"t go out of my way for the  slight foul taste mixed in this dark beer.  Drank it yesterday and had no problem finishing it.
A nice change from the traditional Heineken lager. Strong roasted aroma and after taste. An enjoyable beer to have.
light roasted coffee aroma - reminds me of waking up to the smell of a pot of coffee.  pours a thick creamy head that sticks around awhile.  good beer to enjoy with friends on a rainy day.

This stops just short of being foul.  Unfortunately gifted to me by an old friend and her bf who like it quite a bit, but I found it hard to finish the glass and eventually gave the rest to my mom, who was chilling with me in the hot tub that night.  Terrible shallow, sticky, paper-flavored stale malt with cloying sweet palate and no depth of flavor.

Bottle with 4.9% alc. Deep brown colour with a nice light brown head. Bit sweet aroma of roasted malts and some chocolate. The flavour has a good bit roasty maltiness, bit of chocolate,  caramel. The finish is sweet with some bitterness. 
Earlier Rating: 1/22/2007 Total Score: 3
Dark Heinies...those were the days drinking loads of this brew. Nice dark brown colour with a good lasting medium beige head. Aroma of caramel, roasted malts, slight chocolate. Good malty flavour with caramel, some raisins, dark chocolate. Roasty sweet finish. A pretty good tasting beer. Among the best Heineken beers.

I tried this once because the only other choices were budweiser and heineken.  I actually enjoyed it.  I couldn’t believe heineken had made a beer worth drinking and it had been overshadowed by their watery light ale.  Roasty, sweet with bitter finish, nice carbonation.
I am a big Heineken fan and this is a nice change of pace. Doesn’t have the aftertaste of regular of Heineken and tastes slightly sweeter. Good overall beer.
Pours dark with a tan head. Strong malt flavor. not really balanced. bitter aftertaste.

Pours a clear, dark brown, with a massive tan head.  I’ve never thought much of Heineken.  But, this beer puts them back on my radar.  Much more of an altbier, or even a schwarzbier, this dark beer has a rich malt flavor with a bit of smokiness.

This is a nice malty, roasted dark lager. Relatively dark in color with a mild aroma. Has a long finish, probably a little too long. A good winter beer and yes, surprising that it comes from Heineken.

Roasty, resin, dough, cough drop, licorice, light sweetness, llightly sour, very bitter, medium body, slick feel, average carbonation, long finish, Very dark. Almost gives you a headache from drinking this coffee-like lager.

Bottled.  Poured a nice lookin’ clear medium garnet with a moderate cap of creamy beige head.  Nose was of non-descript sweet darker malts, chocolate-covered plums, and some more sweetness.  Flavor was of chocolate, toffee, and artificially-sweetened caramel.. light bitterness that I cannot place the source of.  Very drinkable.  Light-medium body and fairly smooth on the palate with grainy points.

12oz bottle from Florian’s.  Dark brown body with ruby-red highlights and about a half an inch of tan head that dissipates quickly leaving only a little lacing.  Smells malty and roasty, with somewhat of a licorice or banana-like quality.  Tastes slightly roasty, sweet, and licorice-like quality.  Medium in body.  Not particularly offensive, but not wow-ing either.  Seems like a Schwarzbier (like Sam Adams Black Lager), but only about half-way to where it should be IMO.  Imressive for a Heinekin product, and a pretty decent beer overall.

Amazingly this is packaged in a brown bottle. That is a step in the right direction. Not a whole lot here, but more than I was expecting. The nose is lacking, but there is enough on the palate to keep ones attention. I wish this was in a can, because it would make for a nice camping beer.
Pours quite dark, really suprised, however taste is mostlly sweetness, not much going on here, apretty standard malted lager. but better than I expected for heineken.

Bottle. Interesting. In every sense this beer reminds me of Red Stripe. Sweet, silky caramel-like aftertaste. Not bad. Much better than the "regular" Heineken sewage. Goes down nicely with none of that skunkiness you’d expect from a Heineken product.

More interesting, I suppose, than their regular lager. Beautiful, dark ruby color, but lacking a decent head. Some faint lacing. Mild, sweet, roasted malt aroma, and the same can be said about the flavor. Light, chocolate note in the finish. Pretty average beer, and not worth going out of the way for.

Pours deep brown with an amber hue and a tan head that falls to a film. Slightly chocolatey in the aroma, mainly malty. The body has a decent creamy feeling, but is still a bit thin. Predominatly malty. Touch of kilned flavors, doughyness, metallic chocolate malt character. Drinkable, not terrible.
Bottle. Nice dark brown color with a fair head. I like this better than regular Heineken because I like dark beer. Still, if you want a good dark beer you can do better than this.

12 oz bottle. Brown amber-ish color with thin tan head. Sweet aroma of caramel malts and a touch of cereal. Malt flavor is a bit one dimensional but tasty with sweet caramel maltiness. There’s some faint hops.

i had this a bunch a few years ago and had it reviwed but i guess the two darks were the cause(one being a dunkel .the other being a bock..but know one seems to get that..????)...ok beer, needs a rerate to make sure.

Bottle from Beerhandy- Pours deep chestnut , 10w30 looking. Head is fizzy, three fingered, beige, and lasts about 20 seconds. Aroma is boring with some roasty malts, coffee, and some hops. FLavours are muteed molasses, some chocolate, slight hops bitterness. It’s pretty boring all the way around, finishes watery and unmemorable. Thanks Chris!
Dark ruby color with a big beige head.  Aroma of caramel malt. Flavor of caramel and molasses. Somewhat bitter. Better than regular Heineken.
Nice taste, but a bit unrefined.  This one has to decide whether it’s going to be a classy beer or a rugged standard one.
Looks much better than it tastes.  Nothing I would have again.  Slightly better than regular Heineken.  There are much better dark beers in this price range than this.

Clear reddish brown with a fairly large head and surprisingly good lacing. Aroma is caramel, hints of darker malts and fruits, light molasses. Crisp mouthfeel that I hate, virtually no bitternerss. Watery texture, fairly light bodied. More boring than anything.
Nice head, wonderful aroma. Dark appearance, carmel and molasses flavor, with a smooth, clean finish. Nice!
Dark pour with light head.  Aroma not very good and taste not much better.  A rather poor pick.

12 oz bottle (also had it in the bottle).  Aroma was mild with hops, caramel and hints of smokiness.  Taste was a lot better than I expected-- very heavy molasses flavors with little activity; wheat and caramel are underlying flavors with a dry finish.  Would definately buy again, not bad from Heineken!

Picked this one up in Kyoto, Japan. A pretty decent bottle shop with some rarites from the area, as well as some notables (Young’s Old Nick and La Fin du Monde). It was a nice change from all of the Asian lagers I had been into, and settled on grabbing a few. It’s been 5 months since I bought it. I drank the Old Nick and the Aventinus along the river. In Japan you can drink wherever you like, on the street, in stores, even in cabs. Great place but I digress. Pours ruby with a very short lived tannish head. Lots of Carb. Aroma is heavy with thinned molases and toasted barley and grains, brown sugar and brown bread crusts. Palate is on the sweet side, but it is a carry over from the Aroma. Finish is dry but has a light lingering of cereal and a trace of cola-esqueishness. All in all the story was better than beer found. As it doesn’t show up very often, it was fun to find but was nothing special. It was also the first beer I have rated in 4 months.
Brown with a fizzy head.  Nose was of caramel, something fruity, and a hint of malt.  Dry in the mouth, kinda watery.  Not bad for its style, much better than regular Heineken.
12 oz bottle.  Suprised.  Medium Brown pour with just a fizzy head.  Aroams were quite nice.  Caramel, Vanilla... Much maltiness.  Very Bock like.  Not too bad really.

From a 12 oz. stubby brown bottle with a coded freshness date on the lower left corner of the back label.

Poured a slightly hazy ruby hued brown with a foamy off-white head that settled into a thin lacing.

Aromas of dark sweet fruits and bready malts.

Moderate carbonation and lightly crisp, smooth light bodied mouthfeel.

Bland, but pleasant tasting, sweet, sugary dark bready malts, a touch of grain along with a light powdery cocoa that balance outs the sugary malts, a subtle fruitiness that adds to the sweetness, a very soft hop bitterness towards the end and a dryish sweet, cocoa malty finish, pretty decent lager drinkability.

I’ve been to a lot of restaurants where this is easily the best choice from the bar, goes well with your typical restaurant chain hamburger.

Pours a deep clear reddish brown, tinges of mahogany. thin tan head with no lace at all. Smells of caramel malt. Lighlty fruity.

Mouth is malty and flabby. None of the richness of the nose is evident in the flavor at all. Limp and weak. Some faint herbal hops. lightly fizzy and really thin. Nothing particularly appealing about this one. Way worse than regular Heineken. Pass.
Bottle.  Mild chocolate malt aroma.  Dark brown with small head.  Slightly sweet barley malt flavor with mild hops finish.  Very tasty - a very nice beer.
Reddish brown, decent head. Much smoother than regular Heinies. Very malty, hardly any bitterness, not a whole lot of hop presence. WAY better than regular Heineken.
has a sweet caramel aroma, and the taste is  a sweet caramel offering as well.  deffiantly better then the standard heineken.

I really enjoy the dark ’Heine’ over the standard or light offering.  Can drink this all night, getting f*d up and going broke at the same time.  Excellent imported lager from a Worldwide leader in Beer.  Darkness is easily recognizable with malt greatness with a typical, smooth finish.

Brownish red with a tight tan head. Barely noticeable sweet, malty aromas. Somewhat weak dark malt flavors with a bit of graininess. Fairly decent, inoffensive, no bitterness, better than standard Heineken. Brown bottle helps, but there was still a slight off taste.
Earlier Rating: 11/18/2003 Total Score: 3.3
Very dark, topped with a light beige head, and a sweet aroma. Mild, with a medium body consisting of light caramel malt flavors and very smooth aftertaste. Seemed to be well balanced and suprisingly better than regular Heineken.

Pours brown.  Very heineken-tasting with a hint of nuttiness.  A little better than I expected, though.  Extremely subdued flavor with hints of hoppiness. The more I drink it, the less I like it.  I am getting drunk though, which is always a plus.

Medium brown color, a bit of redish hued light at the bottom of the glass, and a toast colored small head on top.  Requisite malts are present, sugar and maple scented as they are.  A mild mold note that almost comes across as grass, but alas there don’t seem to be any hops in the scent.  Mostly fizzy, medium chewy thickness, flavors mostly absent until the back of the tongue and finish, which have the staleness of cardboard and twigs, with a light touch of maple and brown sugar thrown in for good measure.  Some alcohol-like flavors in the back, though they are most likely fuesal notes I’m getting.  This one gets a drawn out "meeeeehhhhh".
Eh, Tastes a lot like Heineken.  I’ve had better dark lagers.  Kind of flavorless, with not a whole bunch of anything special about it.
I don’t feel like writing a real review, but it’s pretty alright. I’d prefer the Sam Adams black lager over it, though. About the same price, close in style, but much much better.

This one impressed me, especially since I dont like regular heineken.  I was expecting a crappy dark twist on their regular beer.  What I got was much better, but still not an excellent beer.
